ArticleTitle.sentence: Cellular redox status influences both cytotoxic and NF-kappa B activation in natural killer cells.

AbstractText.sentence: The role of cellular redox status in both cytotoxic activity and NF-kappa B activation in natural killer (NK) cells was investigated.

event.clue: The role of cellular redox status in both cytotoxic activity and NF-kappa B activation in natural killer (NK) cells was investigated.

AbstractText.sentence: The results indicate that stimulation of NK cells, either freshly isolated from peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBL) or long-term cultured NK clones, with specific cell targets results in an increased binding activity of NF-kappa B and AP-1 transcription factors measured by gel retardation.

AbstractText.sentence: Pretreatment of NK cells with the antioxidant pyrrolidine dithiocarbarmate (PDTC) leads to the inhibition of NF-kappa B activation but the AP-1 binding to DNA was superinduced.

AbstractText.sentence: The inhibition of NF-kappa B by PDTC paralleled with an inhibition of spontaneous cytotoxicity mediated by NK cells.

AbstractText.sentence: Moreover, the inhibitors of serine proteases, N-alpha-tosyl-L-lysine chloromethyl ketone and N-alpha-tosyl-L-phenylalanine chloromethyl ketone, also blocked the cytolytic activity of NK cells against the sensitive target K562.

AbstractText.sentence: In contrast, NK activity was not affected by pretreatment of the effector cells with the proteasome inhibitor N-acetyl-leu-leu-norleucinal which selectively inhibits NF-kappa B activation.

AbstractText.sentence: Altogether, these results support the hypothesis that the activation of NK cells involved transcriptional and post-transcriptional events, and that reactive intermediates may play an important role in the molecular processes related with the generation of a cytotoxic response by NK cells.
